title: L1 Capital pushes case for $2b Iluka Resources demerger
text:
Amid some positive performance figures – investors said L1's long/short strategy was up 20 per cent for 2019 to date after fees and had recorded eight positive months to the end of September – L1 is expected to prosecute the case that the royalty could be worth $2.1 billion to $2.4 billion on a net present value basis.

It argues the royalty should trade at a modest premium to non-precious metals peers because of the size and quality of the underlying iron ore operations.

L1 would like to see the royalty distributed to Iluka investors via an in-specie distribution, similar to the way Wesfarmers demerged Coles last year or when BHP Billiton spun off South32 in 2015.

It comes as Iluka shares hit a 2½ year low in August at $6.81 and last traded at $8.35.

"The timing [for a demerger] is perfect," L1 joint managing director and chief investment officer Rafi Lamm told Street Talk.

L1 Capital's Raphael Lamm (left) and Mark Landau. Eamon Gallagher

"We’ve seen a step change lower in global bond yields that has driven a very significant re-rating of the value of royalty assets. This value uplift has not yet translated into a stronger Iluka share price, which is why we believe a demerger of its MAC royalty makes so much sense.

"There are absolutely no synergies between the mineral sands division and the MAC royalty and the assets appeal to a different set of investors. Ultimately, Iluka shares are trading way below fair value, because the royalty is currently hidden within Iluka’s corporate structure.

"We are confident that other shareholders would see the commercial logic in a demerger of the MAC royalty and we have provided a very thorough explanation of the logic for the demerger in our latest quarterly report."

It comes as Iluka is set to front fund managers at an investor briefing on October 31.
description: Mineral sands miner Iluka Resources is under pressure to spin off a valuable iron ore royalty in a move that could unlock about $2 billion in value for shareholders.
